The aforementioned contrast is between (70d) and (70e). Assuming that PP extraposition is rightward movement of the extraposed constituent, we must ask why a PP that is introduced by a focus particle cannot be extraposed. As seen from (70f), focus particles can occur within extraposed PPs; they just cannot introduce them.

Barbiers's account of this fact relies on a general account of the syntax–semantics mapping that he proposes and motivates within that work, and a detailed account of that proposal is beyond the scope of this chapter. Briefly, he proposes a principle of semantic interpretation:

(71)
(Barbiers 1995: 4.10) Principle of Semantic Interpretation:
I. A node Z establishes a S(EMANTIC)-RELATION between a node X and a node Y iff X immediately c-commands Z and Z immediately c-commands Y.
II. Z is a QUALIFIER of X iff Z establishes a S(emantic)-relation between X and Y, and X and Y are coindexed.
Barbiers, in his chapter 2, defends a notion of c-command that differs somewhat from standard definitions. It is presented as (72) (his chapter 4, fn. 7):

(72)
a C-command:
X c-commands Y iff
(i) X does not dominate Y and Y does not dominate X
(ii) There is a (connected) path of left branches from Z, the minimal node that dominates X and Y, to X
b. Immediate c-command
X immediately c-commands Y iff X c-commands Y and there is no closer c-commander W such that X c-commands W and W commands Y
c. Connected path of left branches
Two paths of left branches A and B are a connected path of left branches AU B iff there is no node that intervenes between the two paths

Armed with this machinery, we are now in a position to describe Barbiers's analysis of extraposition. In essence, the Principle of Semantic Interpretation yields the syntactic configurations for the modification relation (or the Qualifier Relation), and, assuming Chomsky's (1986b) Principle of Full Interpretation, an element that occurs at LF that receives no interpretation causes the structure to be ruled out. A PP argument of a verb must be interpreted as a qualifier of the VP. In order to accomplish this, such PP arguments are generated as left-adjuncts of the VPs of which they are arguments, and the VP then moves leftward to the specifier position of the PP adjunct. Hence, the partial initial structure of (73) (the unfocused variant of (70a), (74):
(73) Jan heeft in een stad gewerkt.
(74) Jan heeft [VP [PP in een stad] [VP gewerkt]].

The aforementioned movement of the adjoined VP to the specifier of its adjunct PP can take place either before or after Spell Out (Chomsky 1995c), i.e., either overtly or covertly. In any event, the VP movement is motivated by the need to establish the qualification relation, and the LF is, in the essential respects, (75):
(75) Jan heeft [VP [PP [VPi gewerkt] [PP [P in] [DP een stad]]] [VP ti].

In other words, the extraposition phenomenon is really the leftward movement of the host of the extraposition, in this analysis, motivated to yield the requisite qualification configuration. If the VP and its argument PP do not end up in this configuration, and if there is no other interpretation available, the structure will run foul of the Principle of Full Interpretation.

In fact, this is what happens in (70d), in Barbiers's account. In his analysis of focus particles (Barbiers 1995: chapter 3), the focus particle must immediately c-command either its semantic argument or the trace of its semantic argument. The semantic argument can be either a temporal object or a numeral object; in the former case, it corresponds to a VP, and in the latter case, it corresponds either to a DP or to a PP that contains the DP. It seems that FocPs can be generated as left-adjuncts of any maximal projections. However, FocPs must also be interpreted as qualifiers of their semantic arguments, and must hence be in the requisite configuration with respect to the constituents that denote those semantic arguments. With this in mind, the underlying structure of all of the sentences in (70) is (76):
(76) Jan heeft [VP [FocP pas] [VP [PP in een stad] [VP gewerkt]]].
Given that the lowest VP must first move into the Spec of the PP adjunct in order to license the PP as its qualifier, the next structure would be (77):
(77) Jan heeft [VP [FocP pas] [VP [PP [VPi gewerkt] [PP in een stad]] VPi t]]].

The movement of VP into the Spec of its PP adjunct may be either overt or covert, as can be the movement into [Spec, FocP]. If the highest PP, with the VP filling the specifier, moves into [Spec, FocP], the focus particle is interpreted as a qualifier of the PP, so that the qualifier would receive a numeral-associated interpretation. Covert movement into [Spec, FocP] of the PP would yield (70b), if movement of the VP into [Spec, VP] is overt. If VP movement into [Spec, PP] is covert, and movement of PP into [Spec, FocP] is covert, we get (70a).

To derive a temporal interpretation for the focus particle, the VP must occupy the focus particle's Spec. This could be accomplished by moving the highest VP overtly into the Spec of FocP, and would correspond to (70c). (70d) is marginally possible, according to Barbiers, with a temporal interpretation, but is ungrammatical with a numeral association for the focus particle, because there is no derivation that would place the focus particle into the requisite configuration with the PP so as to allow it to receive a numeral-associated interpretation.

Barbiers's argument, however, is somewhat weak, in that it seems to over-predict the possibilities with respect to the interaction of focus particles and extraposition (here construed as leftward movement). Overt movement of the VP into Spec PP would cause the VP PP configuration to be a PP. This PP with filled Spec should be permitted to move to [Spec, FocP], where the focus particle will immediately c-command its trace. The result would be (70c), which would simply differ from (70b) in that the latter would involve covert movement into [Spec, FocP], while the former would involve overt movement of the large PP into [Spec, FocP]. Hence, this argument for PP extraposition involving leftward movement is problematic.

subsection.heading: 7 Variant of the stranding analysis
subsection.p: Wilder (1995) proposes a variant of the stranding analysis in which the ‘extraposed’ material is not stranded, but rather a larger constituent containing the material is L-moved, leaving a copy of this larger constituent in the original position. The material that appears as extraposed is in fact deleted in the L-moved position, and everything but this material is deleted in the right copy position. To illustrate with a noun-complement that appears in extraposed position, consider (78) (Wilder's (64)), in which bolding indicates deletion:
(78) We talked [about the claim that Mary will hire Peter] yesterday [about the claim that Mary will hire Peter]
As Wilder notes, his analysis requires the possibility of non-constituent deletion, exemplified in the rightmost deletion in (78).

An advantage of Wilder's analysis is that it accounts for the fact that the extraposed material is not c-commanded by the position in which it is interpreted (in rightward movement accounts, the trace does not c-command its antecedent).

Nevertheless, it seems that there are some aspects of the deletion analysis that are extremely problematic. First, it seems that it over-predicts the reconstruction possibilities. Since the phenomenon of extraposition results from deletion of material at PF, it predicts that the ‘extraposed’ material will reconstruct to the position in which the material is interpreted, i.e., the L-moved copy of the larger constituent. As Buring and Hartmann (1997a) (cited by Wilder) point out, this prediction is valid for Condition C reconstruction effects when the extraposed material is a noun-complement:

(79)
(based on) Wilder's (53a):
*We talked [about heri claim___] yesterday that Maryi will hire Peter.
However, Fox and Nissenbaum (1999) point out, citing Taraldsen (1981) as the original source of the observation, that extraposed relative clauses do not reconstruct:

(80)
(Fox and Nissenbaum's (11b)):
I gave himi an argument yesterday that supports Johni's theory.
Hence, the conflation of both relative clause extraposition and noun complement extraposition is viewed by Fox and Nissenbaum, to whom we will turn in the next section, as inappropriate.

The allowance of non-constituent deletion that is exemplified in (75) also seems problematic. For example, VP ellipsis is standardly viewed as deleting a constituent, and this assumption seems justified by the impossibility of deleting, e.g., a verb plus small-clause subject, leaving the predicate, as in (81):
(81) *Although I don't consider him intelligent, I do consider him ambitious.

The allowance of non-constituent deletion that is required in this analysis seems overly powerful as well. For example, it would seem to allow deletion of the verb plus object in a VP-fronting construction, stranding the object relative, which was shown to be impossible, as in (15f), repeated here:
(15) f. *John said that he would call people up who are from Boston, and call people up he did___who are from Boston.
It would also seem to predict extraposition out of a fronted PP, as in (10), repeated here:
(10) *In which magazine did you see it which was lying on the table?

Furthermore, by taking extraposition to be a reflex of deletion of part of the copy of a leftward-moved constituent, it has no account of the Perlmutter–Ross phenomenon of relative clauses with split antecedents, as in (50).

subsection.heading: 8 All extrapositions are not created equal: a mixed analysis of the phenomenon
subsection.p: Fox and Nissenbaum (1999; also Fox 2002) propose that relative clause extraposition be separated analytically from complement extraposition. For the latter, they propose rightward movement of the complement. For the former, they adopt the view that relative clauses, as adjuncts, should be merged late with the constituents which they modify. Specifically, they propose that extraposed relative clauses are in fact merged with QRed nominals which are interpreted as the heads of those relative clauses, and that QR should be viewed as adjoining the nominal to the right of the projection that immediately dominates the nominal before QR. They propose that the distinction between covert and overt operations be eliminated and replaced by a distinction between pronunciation of the head of a chain (the traditional overt movements) and pronunciation of the tail of a chain (the traditional covert movements). The derivation of, e.g., (82) would be as in (83):
(82) John picked a book up which he really enjoyed.

(83)
a. [CP John [VP picked a book up]] [CP which he really enjoyed].
QR yields:
b. [CP John [VP [VP picked a book up] [DP a book]]] [CP which he really enjoyed].
Merger of the relative clause:
c. [CP John [VP [VP picked a book up] [DP [DP a book] [CP which he really enjoyed]]]]].
PF deletion of the head of the QRed nominal chain (represented by bolding):
d. [CP John [VP [VP picked a book up] [DP [DP a book] [CP which he really enjoyed]]]]].

The analysis has some noteworthy aspects. First, because it ties relative clause extraposition to QR, it captures the Guéron and May claim that extraposition of relatives is tied to the QR of the head. Second, because this analysis relies on merger of the extraposed relative in its overt position, it never places it within the constituent that immediately dominates the host's overt position; this accounts for the fact that relatives that are extraposed from object position do not reconstruct to the overt position of the object, exemplified in (80). Because complement extraposition is analyzed as involving rightward movement, by contrast, extraposed complements do reconstruct, as in (79).

It is tempting to apply this analysis of relative clause extraposition to the split antecedence phenomenon, by applying QR in across-the-board fashion for both conjuncts, as in the wh-movement example in (84):
(84) What did John give to Sally and Bill give to Martha?
The Perlmutter–Ross example would be derived as in (85):

(85)
a. [[a man entered the room] and [a woman left]] [who were similar (QR from both conjuncts yielding (b))
b. [[[DP a man] entered the room] and [[DP a woman] left]] [DP [DP a man] and [DP a woman]]] [who were similar] (merger of the relative clause to the conjoined DP yields (c)
c. [[[DP a man] entered the room] and [DP a woman] left]] [DP [DP [DP a man] and [DP a woman]] CP who were similar]]

It is true that the two nominals in the Perlmutter–Ross example would have to be distinct, but it is possible for two distinct nominals to move across the board, as can be seen from the overt example in (86), with across-the-board topicalization, in a respectively-coordination sentence:
(86) This booki and that magazinej John bought ti at Borders and Bill bought tj at Dalton's respectively.

In fact, we can even derive the parallelism constraints on relative-clause extraposition noted in (50), in which the split antecedents cannot consist of a subject in the first conjunct and an object in the second conjunct, if we assume, following May (1985), that object QR is adjunction to VP, while subject adjunction is QR to TP. There would be no way to create a conjoined DP after QR in such cases to host merger of the relative clause.

There is one noteworthy consequence of the Fox–Nissenbaum analysis of relative clause extraposition, whose salient features are rightward QR followed by late merger of the relative clause. Recall Culicover and Rochemont's (1997) observation, discussed in section 2, that fronted wh-phrases can host extraposed relatives, based on the contrast in (13) and (14), repeated here:
(13) *Hei [VP [VP invited several girls to the party] [CP that Johni dated in high school]].
(14) How many girls did [IP hei invite to the party] [CP that Johni dated in high school]?

In other words, the extraposed relative in (14) must be adjoined to a projection that takes it out of the c-command domain of the subject, presumably CP, in order to ensure that the coindexing indicated in (14) does not cause a Principle C violation. However, in Fox and Nissenbaum's approach, we are led to first right-adjoin the object to CP, as a parallel to their analysis of QR, before moving the wh-phrase to [Spec, CP]. This movement of wh-phrases to the right edge of CP before moving to their final resting place is, to the best of our knowledge, unattested, and we are hard pressed to explain the reason for this movement, particularly in a theory which posits movement as a last resort.

We are also hard pressed to explain, in the late merger theory of relative clause extraposition, why reduced relatives do not appear in extraposed position, so that the only phrases that occur in the extraposition construction are PPs and CPs.

subsection.heading: 9 Result clauses
subsection.p: Finally, another construction that seems to have some affinities with extraposition is the degree-complement construction that is exemplified in (87):

(87)
a. John was so hungry that he would eat anything.
b. John was too angry for us to talk to him.
c. John was hungry enough that he would eat anything.
d. John was hungry enough to eat anything.

There is a dependency between the underlined degree words and the clausal phrases to suggest a level of representation at which the clausal phrase is a complement of the degree word. For one thing, the clausal phrase cannot appear without the degree word's presence; for another, the finiteness value of the clausal phrase is determined by the particular degree word, such that so requires that the clause be finite, too that it be non-finite, and enough allows either (88c–d):

(88)
a. *John was hungry that he would eat anything.
b. *John was angry for us to talk to him.
c. *John was so hungry to eat anything.
d. *John was too tired that he ate anything.

With these considerations, early analyses of degree phrases posited representations in which the degree word and the clause formed a constituent, in which the clause was a complement of the degree word. An obligatory extraposition process would then move the clause rightward, so that, e.g., (87a) would include (88) in its derivational history:
(89) John was [AP [Deg″ [Deg′ [Deg so] [C″ that he would eat anything]]]].
It has been noted, however, by Liberman (1974) that, unlike the extraposition of relative clauses that we have been considering, a degree complement can have multiple antecedents:
(90) So many people read so many books so often that it's hard to keep track of them.
Moreover, there can only be one degree complement in a clause:
(91) *So many people read so many books so often that the lines are immense that we have to restock the shelves that the bookstores are making a mint.
The possibility of split antecedents for the degree complement contrasts with the impossibility of split antecedents for the extraposed relative clause, discussed above in connection with (50).
Furthermore, as Guéron and May (1984) show, the degree complement can occur in a clause that is higher than theclause in which the degree word resides:

(92)
(Guéron and May's (29a)):
I told her that so many people attended last year's concert that I made Mary nervous.

The fact that (92) does not have the status of a Principle C violation of the binding theory indicates that the result clause, which contains Mary, must be higher in the tree than the matrix object object pronoun. Given that the degree word resides in tell's complement CP in overt syntax, extraposition of the degree complement into the matrix clause would violate the Right Roof Constraint.

As Guéron and May note, however, the degree word can scope out of the clause in which it overtly resides. Hence, (93), originally noted by Liberman (1974), seems to have two understood interpretations, represented by the following logical forms (Guéron and May's (33)):
(93) Mary believed that Harry is so crazy that he acted irrationally.

The first interpretation of (93), corresponding to (94a), is one in which the extent of Harry's craziness is within the scope of Mary's beliefs, such that Mary believed that Harry's craziness was to such an extent that he acted irrationally. In the second interpretation of (93), corresponding to (94b), Mary believed to such an extent that Harry is crazy that her beliefs caused him to act irrationally.

These two interpretations are claimed to correlate with the syntactic position of the result clause, such that the result clause is analyzed as being adjoined to the CP in which the degree word takes scope. Matrix interpretation of the degree word is said to correlate with the attachment of the result clause to the matrix CP, and this is analyzed by Guéron and May as a reflex of the head–complement relation being established at LF, a view that has become extremely consonant with the tenets of Minimalism (Chomsky 1995c), in which LF and PF are the only two significant linguistic levels. Therefore, the interpretation of (93), given that the result clause is adjoined to the matrix clause, is one in which the degree word must take matrix scope.
